text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A man lives on the 10th floor of an apartment building.
Every morning he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
When he returns in the evening, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and then walks up the stairs to reach his apartment on the 10th floor.
However, on rainy days and when other people are in the elevator, he goes directly to the 10th floor in the elevator.

Why does he normally get off on the 7th floor? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I'm trying to figure out why the man gets off the elevator on the 7th floor every morning.
Let me break this down step by step.
First, the man lives on the 10th floor.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor.
That makes sense because he's going to work.
Now, when he returns in the evening, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and then walks up the stairs to his apartment on the 10th floor.
But on rainy days or when other people are in the elevator, he goes directly to the 10th floor.

So, why does he normally get off on the 7th floor?

Hmm, maybe it's about the elevator's behavior.
On normal days, when it's not raining and there aren't too many people, the elevator might not go all the way up to the 10th floor.
But why? Maybe the elevator only goes up to the 7th floor? Or perhaps the man wants to save time or avoid waiting for the elevator to go higher.
Wait, another possibility is that the elevator doesn't go beyond the 7th floor on normal days.
Maybe the building's elevator has a limit.
So, when he takes it down in the morning, it stops at every floor, but in the evening, if it's not crowded and not rainy, he can get off at the 7th floor and then walk up.
But on rainy days or when there are other people, the elevator goes all the way to the 10th floor because it's more efficient or because the man prefers it.
So, putting this together, the man gets off on the 7th floor normally because the elevator doesn't go higher than that on non-rainy, non-crowded days.
He can then walk up the stairs to his apartment.
But when it's rainy or crowded, the elevator goes directly to the 10th floor, saving him the walk.
I think that makes sense.
The key point is the elevator's usual behavior versus special conditions.

</think>

The man gets off the elevator on the 7th floor because, on normal days, the elevator only stops there.
He then walks up the stairs to his 10th-floor apartment.
On rainy days or when the elevator is crowded, it goes directly to the 10th floor, allowing him to skip the stairs.
